Reviews.title: Underrated, Worth every penny, Old reliable.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2022
Reviews.text:
Got this card just a few months before Covid had the GPU market going bonkers, it has served me well ever since. AMD drivers have been a rollercoaster throughout but as you browse forums/use more recent patches, the card is more stable than ever. Used to be a nightmare getting random black screens or whole system restarts. For the original MSRP, this card still holds its ground well with the current generation of cards at a similar or even higher price point. Can't recommend it enough.
Additional notes, I've had it overclocked & undervolted since the first day, playing intensive games like Escape From Tarkov on intensive settings and besides getting the fans roaring, the card still runs without a hiccup. Definitely one of my best tech purchases.

Reviews.title: great budget GPU
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2022
Reviews.text: I got this XFX RX 5500 XT 8gb back in 2020 for my very first PC build. Was little skeptical about XFX just because I've always heard from the big brands like Asus or MSI. I decided to go for this brand just because of the price and my budget at the time. I've play all of my games with no issue so far on 1080p between 100-170 fps and recently on 1440p running about 70 fps on Warzone and 40 on Horizon Zero dawn at high settings both games. Even though it sounds like a low number at 40 fps Horizon runs very smooth. This GPU can be a little loud at times but nothing to crazy, Ive never tried to OC this graphics card and I don't think you have much room to do that with this card but overall nothing to regret about getting this item

Reviews.title: Decent Card.. Underrated.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2020
Reviews.text:
I got the 5500xt 8GB model. I’ll start by saying that I originally bought this just as a “cheap” place holder for my new build until Big Navi was released. The reviews on it aren’t great but most of them just complain that the price is too high. I can kind of agree with this because the next step up is the 5600XT at $100 or less extra and the performance from the 5500 to the 5600 is night and day. But that’s not to say the 5500xt isn’t a good GPU. It got my 1080p gaming done at over 60FPS in most titles on max or near max settings. This is definitely a 1080p card. But it can perform somewhat at 1440p if you’re willing to tinker with some settings.

Over all I think this is a decent buy for anyone looking for a very good and cheap 1080p experience. Anything above 1080p and you’ll want to move up to the 5600xt or 2060 depending on if you’re an AMD or Nvidia person respectively.

I got this card for $200 new and that’s probably the max I would spend on a 5500xt 8GB. Anything higher and you may as well move up to the 5600xt.

Also, I’ve had two AMD cards since August (5500xt and 5600xt) and I’ve never had any driver issues at all. So either I got lucky or AMD got their driver problems resolved. I’ll stick with AMD over Nvidia as long as AMD makes cards that give me the level of performance I’m looking for.

Reviews.title: Good performance, great value, VERY QUIET!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2020
Reviews.text:
Bought this card to replace a second hand GTX 760 that finally gave up the ghost and completely failed after 7 years. This card met and exceeded my expectations in every category.

The performance is great for a $200 card, it has been able to handle every game I’ve thrown at it on 1080p with a mixture of high and ultra settings no problem. The biggest surprise for me though was just how quiet this card is! Even under 100% load the fan is so quiet that I can’t even hear it.

Overall an excellent budget card for 1080p and multiple monitors that I would recommend to anyone. I know that some people (and myself temporarily) were put off of this card after looking at the benchmarks, where it only fared marginally better than the 580/590, but when it comes down to it the lower power consumption is 110% worth it. These cards can also overclock very hard (think 2.1 Ghz) if you’re so inclined.

If you have been unable to find a 1660s any where for a reasonable price you can safely purchase this card in a heartbeat, and not be disappointed. I am actually glad that I wasn’t able to find one, and got this 5500xt instead.

Reviews.title: Not a bad Graphics card, when it sold for less than $250
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2021
Reviews.text:
I would've given this a 5 star review because for less than 210USD which was the cost when I purchased it and it's capabilities it was worth it to me, however even after updating drivers and what all was available online for this card, the graphics card still displays a blank screen from time to time, or it turns my screen all 1 color and the only thing that displays is the windows icon and tabs at the bottom, this usually only happens at start up,

How I fix the issue is I go into display config and switch resolution back and forth a few times then my screen pic goes back to normal...

Outside of this persistent issue I haven't had any real issues with this card, I've owned it now for about 5 months and it still works really well with the exception of whats described above, it's still a decent card in my opinion.

As for the asking price increase, theres no way I'd give nearly 600USD for this card, thats my opinion of course.

Reviews.title: Great upgrade for 1440p gaming
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2020
Reviews.text:
I recently upgraded my PC with this graphics card to boost the performance and more specifically the resolution that I am playing at. I recently upgraded to a 4k monitor with HDR and wanted to take more advantage of that extra visual capability. This card will help with that. Depending on your system and the software you are trying to play you can easily get stable 1440p resolution. Low end games are no problem at 4k resolution. As an example I was playing Doom Eternal at 1440p with stable FPS above 60 even during heavy action.

If you are really wanting to play everything in 4k this card might not quite get you there. As a 1440p card though you cannot beat this price point. I highly recommend for this level.

The HDR on the card is ok. This I don't fault as much with the card as the software trying to use it. You can get HDR video and gaming but each game handles it differently and Windows itself is different. The biggest thing I can say here is that you can defiantly do HDR with this card as long as your monitor and all the other setting are set up accordingly.

Reviews.title: On the 8th day, XFX said let there be silence and darkness.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 7, 2020
Reviews.text:
XFX has made one of the best pieces of hardware I could have come across, as you you can tell from the pictures, my computer looks like it was puked on by a radioactive unicorn, but XFX brought a balance that I didn't know I needed with a nice gunmetal casing.

- Noise

As you see, under "no load" the fans shut down, the only hum you hear is the stock case fans. Even at full bore, I can't hear anything, and my machine is a foot and a half from my head! It's a silent killer.

- Performance

Paired with my last gen Ryzen 5 2600x my machine still scored a %96 on user benchmark... Unfortunately, I don't have a monitor that can keep up with the card yet, so it's cutting the FPS, but at ultra settings, I am getting 110FPS in Borderlands WITHOUT Overclocking!

Overall

This is hands down, the best card you can get for the dollar. The RX 5700 XT is ranked 15th, but the performance to dollar amount is not worth the extra doll-hairs you will spend going past. That on top of how sexy XFX has made this monster, I would marry it if I could, but my current wife might kill me with it.

Reviews.title: Solid card for what I paid
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2021
Reviews.text: Bought this for a MBP/bootcamp set up for a little over $300 before prices skyrocketed. Does a fine job for the games I play with most games' settings at 7-8/10, but I went into it knowing it was a middle-of-the-road card. I am running it through a razer core and haven't had any issues with heat though I sometimes have to tweak my display settings on the bootcamp partition, but, that's a minor gripe. All in all, I would recommend this card if you want a card to get the job done but isn't flashy assuming you can find a non-ridiculously priced one somewhere.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2020
Reviews.text: Beautiful card I love the black and chrome and the backplate I also love how the chrome reflects my RGB But to the good stuff you’re looking for. It doesn’t crash and it doesn’t over heat it stays around 55c-75c especially if you set the fans to 50% at all times yet the best part....they aren’t loud it’s so hard to believe but all I hear from them is a slight hum and I had to put my ear to my case to even remotely hear it even then it was hard and don’t get me started on the performance ugh what a 1080p demon with some 1440p capability at Ultra settings comfortably like in 1440p it gets around 50-75 or so FPS depending on the game obviously lol but it’s so much better than what people make it out to be I don’t think I’ll be upgrading for a very very long time around 3-5 years honestly and delivery was fast 2 day shipping, nothing was broken this thicc boy and yes it is very thicc lol it’s a beast if your looking to only spend $300 on a gpu.

Reviews.title: Honest review ( I’m not amazon)
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2020
Reviews.text:
Okay.

Here’s a review from a gaming enthusiast but newbie pc guy.

I upgraded this Card from a 980 8gb as I play on a 4K TV (I know) And wasn’t getting stable or playable frame rates at 1440 or even 1800.

This card changed that game. Some games will run at the TVs highest definitions . Games like Red dead 2 and GTAV are amazing at 1440 even on ultra setting a for the most part. I really couldn’t believe this card was pulling off some of the visuals it was with frames at around 50 FPS.

It’s not perfect by any means, I feel as though I lack power in weird games.. and it’s definitely not good to go for 4K with modern games at the highest settings. Other than that, this game makes my PS4 pro look like a turd...

Reviews.title: HD5770s and 6770s never came with 4GB of VRAM! AVOID!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
The vast majority of HD6770s did not come with a VGA port. The real ones also require a 6-pin power connector. Most cards that have an output layout like this are fake and, seeing reviews from people saying it won't run DX11, I'm inclined to believe this isn't even a 6770 as those did run DX11. The listed clock speed is about 200mhz lower than the original cards which, at best, points to these being faulty cards flashed with a different BIOS to operate at a lower clock speed. HD 5770s and 6770s (same card with 2 names) also NEVER came with 4GB of VRAM.

Again, this points to this being a card with a fake BIOS. I've tested another faked GPU claiming to be a GTX 960 4GB and the card even reported itself as such to the computer. In actuality it was a GT640 with 1GB of VRAM. When a game would try to utilize the reported 4GB of VRAM that didn't exist, it would cause the computer to crash.

Best case scenario here, you get a GPU that was originally released in 2009 (as the 5770, again, identical to the 6770...AMD just renamed the same card 2 years later) which has not received driver support since 2015, running at 76% of it's original speed (which may be how it gets away without a 6 pin power connector...but I doubt it) and have to spend some time dialing in settings to avoid games using more than 1GB of VRAM so the computer won't crash. In other words KEEP SHOPPING!

data.label: MAXSUN AMD Radeon RX 550 4GB Low Profile Small Form Factor Video Graphics Card for Gaming Computer PC GPU GDDR5 ITX SFF HDPC 128-Bit DirectX 12 PCI Express X16 3.0, HDMI, DisplayPort

Reviews.title: It does what I needed it to do
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2022
Reviews.text:
At my workplace I needed this half-height graphics card for a PC running a graphics intensive application that was practically unusable using the on-board graphics on the PC. Installing this card resolved the performance issues. I was pleased enough with that purchase that I bought one for my home computer to resolve some lag issues when playing 4K video on my old PC. This card resolved that issue, too. I don't know how this product benchmarks against the completion. I didn't do any testing like that. I simply had performance issues with applications that needed a graphics card performance boost. The price was right on this graphics card and I found that it worked fine to resolve those issues.

The only issue that I had was that the package came with no English instructions, no drivers and no software. I am an IT technician by trade, so I had little trouble finding the right drivers and software online. On one PC, Windows Update found the drivers, but I still had to download and install the correct version of the Radeon software. On the other PC I had to download both the drivers and software. So, this wasn't much of a problem for me, but it may be more than a novice PC users can deal with.

This product did what I needed and I've had no problems with it either at home or at work. It gets a 5 star rating from me even though I would have expected better instructions for installing the product and obtaining the correct drivers & software.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in Germany on August 29, 2022
Reviews.text:
Diese Grafikkarte ist absolout NICHT VR fähig ! Wer VR möchte MUSS mehr investieren !

Dennoch möchte ich diese Grafikkarte einmal für ihre erstaunliche und herausragende Leistung loben.
Hier hat MAXSUN alles richtig gemacht!

Ich habe einen Rechner mit ordentlich Leistung und natürlich auch mit einer entsprechenden Grafikkarte um damit die Valve Index VR-Brille zu betreiben. Ich bekam ein ausrangiertes Fujitsu Esprimo C710 mit USB3.0 und einem betagten aber ausreichenden Prozessor und suchte nun nach einer Low Profile Grafikkarte, die dabei auch noch schlank und bestmögliche Leistung bringen sollte.

Mein verrückter Plan:
Wenn an meinem Rechner was abraucht, sollte der kleine Esprimo das Ganze überbrücken.
Mit 32GB RAM und der MAXSUN Radeon RX 550 ist mir das sehr gut gelungen.
Wir reden hier natürlich von minimalistischen Grafikeinstellungen ABER BeatSaber, Phasmophobia (SinglePlayer), Pistol Whip und Blade & Sorcery sind durchaus spielbar und die Karte wird dabei nicht übermäßig heiß. Half Life - Alyx hingegen lagt sehr deutlich (wie es auch zu erwarten ist)

Dies ist keine Kaufempfehlung für VR, es soll aber verdeutlichen, was die kleine Karte auf dem Kasten hat.
Denn hier schlägt sie die vergleichbare GT 1030 um längen. Für Titel wie Diablo III und Co ifinde ich die RX 550 völlig in Ordnung und sie macht dort auch eine echt gute Figur.

Fazit: Es gibt natürlich deutlich stärkere Grafikkarten, egal ob AMD oder NVIDIA aber wer bei dem aktuellen Auf und Ab der Grafikkartenpreise eine günstige und verhältnismäßig starke Grafikkarte sucht, weil er sich gerade keine große leisten kann oder wie bei mir für einen kleineren Zweitrechner, sollte hier gut bedient sein.

Reviews.title: I NEEDED A CARD TO CRUISE AROUND THE INTERNET WITHOUT ISSUE AND THIS IS IT!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
I just needed a basic video card to cruise around the internet without being stifled by lame performance of a cheap video card. While this card is a tad expensive it is not priced at the ridiculously insane prices of the middle to high end gaming video cards in 2022. This GPU has done the job of letting me go anywhere on the internet without video lag.

I had a more expensive NVIDIA GPU in my system with otherwise state of the art hardware. The newest most power Ryzen 9 \ 5900 CPU, fast memory and a 750 watt power supply. The NVIDIA GPU ran like hot garbage on my Ubuntu system. Ubuntu has a nasty sepia color scheme that saturates the entire OS and everything in it. It is not only ugly but painful to look at due to my vision issues.

I did not know for sure at the time but, I hoped a new video card from someone other than NVIDIA might perform better. Turns out this AMD designed GPU got rid of the nasty sepia tint. This video card creates a simple un-tinted OS that is a pleasure to use. The card is not BIG and uses only the power supplied by the GPU slot.

The card has some energy saver garbage installed that turns the card off if you power down your monitor. I took a star off for the energy saver mess. There really are no other issues. This is a great card to use on a Linux\Ubuntu system that is not used for hard core gaming.

Reviews.title: It Works...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2022
Reviews.text:
OK, it arrived on time, but that is sort of an issue. When I purchased this product, Amazon guaranteed delivery on Sunday Feb. 6, 2022. On the 6th, I woke up to an email that it would be delayed until Monday the 7th. No problem, we had a blizzard and people have been digging out. BUT, it was delivered on Sunday and just left outside, in the freezing cold and snow, without me knowing or expecting it was going to happen. Luckily, a friend stopped in for five minutes, and by coincidence that's when the package was left in the cold and snow, so it wasn't there when he came up the porch, but it was there when he went down and my package got to me safely. The seller bears no responsibility for this, as it was fulfilled by Amazon, but for some reason, Amazon doesn't let us write reviews for the customer service, so here it is. You can do better, Amazon.

As for the product itself, it's not really as bad as my "stars" would suggest. It arrived in what appears to be brand new packaging. I can't find any evidence that the anti-static bag was ever opened before. I installed it in my aging Dell Inspiron 3700 (with an i5-8400, and 12GB of RAM) hooked it all up, turned it on, and after about 5 minutes of some installation process (at which time there WAS video) my screen automatically reverted to the display settings it had prior to the install, and it works just fine. I installed Nvidia GeForce and, after one more driver update it was over. The entire process was from start to finish was less than 20 minutes.

This was the first time I have ever installed a GPU, and I can only assume that that is EXACTLY how it is supposed to work. As for the value for money, NO GPU has a good value to money ratio. Crypto-miners and the pandemic have seen to that.

As for gaming, this just is NOT a card built to plays today's most advanced games. I got this card because PGA 2K21 can only track one profile at a time, so two people with two profiles need two copies of the game to track their stats in co-op. Now, my aging Dell could manage about 25 FPS in "potato mode," a number that made it unplayable. With this card, on low settings (one step up from potato mode), this card and the i5 deliver 90FPS steadily at 1080p quality.

The problem there, is that 2K21 is really "The Golf Club 3" with 2K's marketing slapped on the box. As such, the entire install from Steam was just 6.6GB. And as every modern gamer knows, the 5-15GB game file size was lost to any game above the 'indie" classification when the games went 4K. Which means that the game would have to still be in potato mode if 4K textures even existed in the files for processing.

The only other "modern" game I have on the Dell is Kerbal Space Program. And that, with low settings turned on, and the FPS locked to 80, this card and the i5 can get maintain a steady 60 in the assembly buildings and launchpad, and dropped into the 40 FPS range during the launches I tested. But that is normal. KSP can make even monster PC's cry for mercy if the user launches a big enough ship. The limitation there is far more CPU dependent than GPU dependent as the game tries to simulate physics, heat, and gravity calculations on hundreds of individual parts simultaneously.

As for video streaming, honestly, I don't see very much improvement over the streaming quality of just the i5, but there is no LESS quality to the streaming, and that's what matters. My monitor is a 32" 1440p, with a 144 Hz refresh rate.

I do, however, have a couple of issues with this card. On the product description page, there is clearly a picture of the various output I expected to find on this card. And if I remember right that picture had a display port, an HDMI port, a 24 pin DVI port, and a VGA port (I might be wrong about the VGA port). The card that arrived at my house, does NOT have either a VGA port or a display port. So, if your monitor has either of those, BUYER BEWARE!!! I was only ever going to use the HDMI port, so I'm not too fussed.

My bigger issue is the plastic shroud on the GPU itself. The card doesn't cover the same amount of area that the plastic shroud does, so I have several square inches of exposed plastic shroud inside my PC, acting as a "bowl" to catch any dust flying around. And while the Dell has a paper filter the covers the main air intake, and a sort of cone directing the CPU exhaust directly out into the room and that has kept the amount of dust inside my case to a minimum. But now there is the GPU fan sourcing air from an unfiltered area, and just exhausting the air inside the case. So, ALL bets are off as to how this plays out in the remaining life left in my aging Dell.

That is just BAD design all the way around. It uses more material than is strictly needed meaning the manufacturer is paying more than is strictly necessary for each card manufactured, and it CAN'T be good for the PC to have an actual dust catcher inside a machine that you work hard to keep dust free. And I can PROMISE the manufacturer, that if my aging Dell suddenly dies six weeks from now, I know EXACTLY who I will blame. I won't get a refund, but THEY won't get a return customer.

And for that reason, ultimately, I will give this GPU a 3-star rating with a serious "BUYER BEWARE" due to the misleading product photos, as well as the poorly designed fan shroud.

Reviews.title: Good Card for Media Center PC, ok for gaming
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2021
Reviews.text: I bought this card because it was basically the only halfway decent card for under $200 due to the price gouging currently in the GPU market. I paired this with a Budget ASRock B450m mother board with a Ryzen 3700x processor, and 16GB of RAM clocked to 3200 mHz. It supports media up to 4k no problem and playback is excellent, no stutters or skips. It does have HD audio output through HDMI up to 7.1 surround and can support Dolby Atmos if your audio system has that feature. This card suits my needs quite nicely for my media center PC. I don't do a lot of gaming but what I have played has been ok. Fornite, Resident Evil: Biohazard, and Call of Duty would all play at 1080p at around 60 FPS which is certainly playable. The GPU would bottleneck as it is just not powerful enough for GPU intensive games. For being passively cooled you need good airflow, I found that the card would not really get above 50 degrees C when gaming, and hovers in the mid to low 30's when playing back media. I overpaid for this card because of the GPU market right now, but it is a decent little card that doesn't draw a lot of power, so almost any system can use it without an issue(it is powered directly from the motherboard, no external power to plug in). Since I use it for a media center PC I am rating 5 stars as it works perfectly for my needs.

Reviews.title: Great for gamers on a budget!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2021
Reviews.text:
Love this card. I had old potato-y tech when I bought this. I.E. an oooold nvidia 8400 that came in an hp desktop my dad gave me out of some surplus tech he had salvaged... yeah. I bought one of these Gt 1030's and slapped it into my hp. Stuck that disk in the reader followed the prompts and boom! It was like I had a totally different machine. Seriously, if you're running on an old card or onboard video and having problems with gameplay with older or semi recent games, this may be a good choice for an upgrade. It is DX11 compatable so that's a thing. For a gamer on a budget it is amazing. I read some other reviews that said it wont run crazy heavy stuff or things at max settings, but if you are on a budget you probably wont be paying a crap ton of money for the latest and greatest. 10/10 from me! Great value for the easily accessible price, which ,at the time of this review, was about $150ish American. Something to keep in mind is that it may have an issue fitting in thinner PCs due to the MASSIVE heatsink. It fit in my pc just fine and I have a smaller hp "compaq." Just watch for wire and make sure you aren't going to crush anything.

It comes with the standard size fixture attached but a smaller one in the box and they are easy to swap out just three little screws and your good. Easy to install hardware and software alike.

Reviews.title: Great affordable card - hitsory of why it is better than a RX460 and RX560
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2018
Reviews.text: Oh what a difference stability makes. This card is solid as a rock - it provides good performance on the desktop and acceptable gaming. If your looking for a 4k card - yeah this isn't it - but it is a good hdmi capable card and does what you ask of it. So while I say this is a great card it is from some sad experiences - I originally tried ASUS ROG STRIX-RX460-4G-GAMING card first. It worked a couple months - then died. Sent back to Asus who sent another in a couple months it died. Next tried a XFX Radeon RX 560 4GB DDR5 with the same sad results. In a couple months it flakes out. I 'think' the problem is with the fan not engaging and while in both cases neither Asus nor XFX provided software to throttle up the fan I find it curious that this card (which doesn't even have a fan) comes with software to guess what - throttle up the %*$()%* fan! So you've been warned honestly just stick with nvidia chips. Even the AMD driver testing is done on the I7 not a AMD machine - check their own notes in driver update notes (I am rolling a fx8300) AMD is pushing a lot of things to market - not particularly ready - not particularly in synch with their vendors and it shows. XFX is a great card maker I have a R9 and R7 card both work great. So it isn't them - learn from my pain and it will be worthwhile. I did order a Saphirre 550x at one point that did not work day 1. Again I suspect this is a hole between AMD and the card maker more than the card makers issue. I set it back same week. If they ever get the drivers and software worked out they will be good cards - but the crashing was so bad I had to reinstall windows it corrupted the FAT table. Yes that bad. So skip the headaches go with a card like this.

Reviews.title: Seems to work great, just not in my PC?
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2019
Reviews.text:
I needed to update my review after running this card for two days:

This card installed fine and was working well for two days, however, on the second day it apparently became too warm/hot and re-booted my HP PC. I decided to remove the TV Tuner card right above it since I don't use it, just to allow even more space, which gave the GT 1030 more room.

I re-booted my PC and in about two hours, my pc re-booted on its own again. I went back into my PC to make sure the card was seated properly, it was, but I noticed that the heatsink was pressing up against a multi-wire plug on the motherboard (the firewire plug). Its smashing the actual wires. If it was just the non-heatsink portion of the card, it wouldn't be a big deal, but because the heatsink gets hot, it could potentially melt those wires.

I'm leaving my review as four stars because I don't know if the problem of re-booting my PC is due to the GT 1030 overheating or the wires it's smashing, because otherwise, the card may be ok.

I guess I'll order a card with a fan, like Gigabyte GT 1030 OC via Amazon. In the meantime, I'm using my seven year old EVGA GT 520.

Reviews.title: Just as good as the fan (non-silent) model; Have Good Ventilation
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2019
Reviews.text:
I had originally purchased the other model with the same name which included a fan on it. I found that the card met my needs exactly and allowed me to play some more intense games without crashing. However, I started having issues with the previous card and I found that those issues almost exclusively took place when the card's fan started. After some research, I came to the conclusion that my itty-bitty power supply was the culprit, and not only that but the manufacturer had intentionally created the power supply so it couldn't be easily upgrade and fit into the case. So I did some more research and found this exact same card, but with no fan and a larger heat sink. For some computers, the heat sink might be so large as to get in the way of other card slots, but for me, I have had NO ISSUES at all, and it works great in my computer for its games.

Update: I tried pushing the video card a bit to see how it would function. After an hour or so of heavier than usual graphics playing, the video started to flicker like it was about to go out. I suspected something like this might happen and do not blame the good quality of the card. The video card ends up with the heat sink in my PC facing downward and air probably doesn't flow well. Just keep in mind this gets a bit warm. Fortunately, it is near a vent and I was able to find a cooling fan I could place on the outside of the PC to compensate.

Reviews.title: Perfect for a HTPC
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2020
Reviews.text:
Using this with some old parts (i3200 CPU, Asrock HM series motherboard) in a small case to create a HTPC. The card streams 4K perfectly and has basically turned my 65" HDTV into a computer monitor running at 4K. Very nice. The integrated graphics in the i3 were not capable of the high resolution. I also do some light gaming with ancient titles, it works well for that too.

The non passive cards are about $40 less. Dunno how loud they are, this one is silent of course. /the case I have has a fan that turns slowly, blowing some air over the card, my monitor software shows the massive heat sink does a great job, with just a whiff of air going over it, the GPU maxes out at 40C after gaming for awhile. I like the fanless and large heat sink design, especially of the case provides some air movement.

Reviews.title: Decent for the money
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2018
Reviews.text:
Gotta say I actually expected more performance from an item that was a pretty far upgrade from my old 650. This 1030 has better memory, GDDR5 x2 GB, better processor, clock speeds and a top of the line 3rd party designer.

Although I did see a small increase in performance with this card, it wasnt much different then the 650(1GB DDR3). Even with the performace tests I did using 3D mark there wasnt a vast increase in FPM, I was pretty surprised at that.

I do like the fact that it dosent use a fan, I have an internal fan that circulates air around the card and that keeps it usually under 50c.

The software thats included with the card, AORUS engine, seems rather a joke and I wonder why they even include it, I see no difference at all in games with it "boosted", and even the 3D mark showed no performance difference at all with it on or off. All about marketing? Probably.

So only 4 stars as I was pretty meh about this card, was hoping for more with the hype and didnt get it. Its decent, and I would rate it as decent, but definitely not spectacular.

Reviews.title: Don't Hesitate at $79.99!!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2018
Reviews.text: Bought this to replace a messed up GTX 460. This card is without a doubt better. No noise, temps are very good and if you decide to overclock the tool that comes on the driver CD is very easy to use. I now can push my desktop resolution to 4K (on HDMI) and at 1080p gaming I have no issues with Diablo 3 or Team Fortress 2 at very high-max settings and I am running a 3.2Ghz AMD Phenom ii X2 555 at stock with 4gb of 1333 DDR3 ram. I ordered this on Saturday and received afternoon MONDAY as promised. Price at 80 bucks is the best you are going to find right now and is right at the price it should be considering the over charging for video cards right now (3/4/18). No power connectors just put it into your pcie slot screw it in and install driver, DONE. It even comes with a low profile bracket if you don't have a full sized slot for a video card. Shipping packaging was adequate and product was brand new and as advertised I even spent less than $2 more for a 4 year protection plan. I highly recommend this product.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2021
Reviews.text: I wanted to get better graphic support - mainly for online gaming. This did the trick and didn't break the bank. It has been very stable in windows 10 64bit; I have had no issues.

Reviews.title: Overheats when pushed. Get the model with a fan.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2019
Reviews.text:
Like the title says, when pushed this guy overheated badly. The idea that a larger heatsink would make up for lack of fan failed in practice. I paired this with an AMD A10-8750 4.2ghz processor and 12gig ram. After set up, I had my son Play Fortnight on medium settings for about 5 minutes and checked the GPU temps. I burned my finger on the heatsink which prompted me to get my infrared temp reader out. I was shocked to see 170*F on the backside of the PCB. Not good. I had to remove a side cover and put a small desk fan blowing on the motherboard and heatsink. That did the trick, temps back down to 100*-110*F under hard load.

It's too bad because it actually worked really well, especially for the price. It was pulling steady 50-60fps with said Fortnight game in med/high settings. Way better than a GT710 or GT730 for not much more cost. Moral of the story is pay an extra 10 bucks and get the unit with a fan and shroud. I'm returning this and just getting a GTX-1050 Ti.

Reviews.title: Insane performance!

Reviews.text: I bought this for my pc, it has an i9 12900kf, 128gb ddr5, and with this graphics card i get a SOLID 60fps on valorant on MEDIUM settings

Reviews.title: Perfect for Plex & Live Streaming Hardware Acceleration
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2019
Reviews.text:
Lets start with a generic review of the 1660. I'm using these for video transcoding for plex & live video streaming. I can get 4 or 5 - 4k 60mbps --> 1080p 20mbps transcodes (encode + decode) going concurrently before I run out of VRAM and the quality is MUCH better than previous generations of Geforce cards thanks to the turing architecture. Live streaming using Vmix can record and stream 4+ 1080p RTMP connections at the same time as well with ease. CPUs are 4790ks on z97 chipset.

Specific to this card. The cooler isn't a top of the line Auorus or Strix caliber but it is solidly built. The logo lights up and cycles through the rgb spectrum. You can turn it off in Windows using afterburner but if you're using Linux, you're kinda stuck with it on. I'm sure there's something on github to turn it off but I haven't bothered. These sit in a server rack, so I never have to see it but I figured I would mention it. The card is cooled very well and I have never noticed it even ramp up past 25% at load. The fans turn off at idle.

Reviews.title: Get a Super instead
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2019
Reviews.text:
Don't get me wrong, I love this card. I just wish I waited a few more months, because the 1660 Super is now the king of value in this price range (it's basically a 1660 ti for ~$100 less). I'd even pick up a $250 Super over a $200 regular, as long as they have the same cooling solution.
The 3X Windforce version stays nice and cool and quiet. I haven't overclocked it yet (as long as my games are smooth I'm happy) but I set a custom fan curve that keeps it under 60c and it's barely audible (though my computer sits about 10 feet away from me)

And 1060 default settings is high and medium Hope by reading this you got an idea why is it good graphics card. For a price range I love it. As well as installing it is very easy I know some cards in 1060 the record doesn't come but with this one it does. I haven't found anything that I can sing negative about this card

Reviews.title: Definitely worth the money.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2019
Reviews.text:
I did a little bit of reading around, weighing out options and budget and this was what I landed on. I've only had it for a short while but I've been loving it. I paired it with a Ryzen 5 2600 and this thing has no problems doing anything I've thrown at it. I don't play on high settings simply because I don't like antialiasing (blurry image) and motion blur and other "bells and whistles" and this thing laughs at everything. Ridiculously high framerates and ridiculously low temps (doesn't exceed 65 degrees under load on ultra settings when I push it. It's in an n200 from coolermaster with all noctua case fans)

I'm glad to have bought this thing.

Reviews.title: Easy to install, super quiet
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2019
Reviews.text: Received the Gigabyte GeForce GTX 1660 Gaming OC 6G Graphics Card today to replace my 5 year old Power Color R9 380. The 380 was in early stages of failure with intermittent flashing and running hot 60C at idle. The install was easy as expected and the 3 fan model runs cool an quiet 40C with the fans are off until 50+C. I have a 1080 monitor with 21 x 9 widescreen and after the drivers were installed the display was perfect. Overall I am happy with the purchase.

Reviews.title: Awesome
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2019
Reviews.text: After doing my research I pulled the trigger. Crammed this thing in my new Lenovo C530, replacing the stock 1050 ti. It barely fit, had to wiggle it in very carefully to install it. The performance is great. I can now run pubg, SW battlefront 2 and all the other games I currently own on ultra settings with no problem. It runs hotter than the 1050ti but I blame the small case/case fans not the card. Even in the crammed case it hasn't exceeded 76c during gaming.

Wow! I am amazed by the improved performance on such a low cost graphics board. I spend hours each week flying a variety of flight sims and have spent more than double the price for top line cards before that provided far less
performance than this inexpensive masterpiece. Well done, Gigabyte! Software includes an easy to use option to set
the cooling fan speed curve that should help with a variety of case designs. Get the card while it's cheap!

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2022

Reviews.title: Very Reliable and Cool temps as Expected from EVGA
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2019
Reviews.text:
If you are reading this, then you probably already did your homework on this card. I will "try" to keep it short

EVGA in the GPU industry is usually regarded as a top tier brand and this card is no different, it provides stable great gaming experience with great temperatures. The overhead for overclocking seems to be decent but as of this writing I didn't fully explore that yet.

If you are considering it for RTX I greatly recommend it but under the following circumstances, for now I only tested it on Battlefield V (Max RTX, Max Graphics) and it provides a stable 60 FPS experience on 1080p. Just to be clear 1080p while using this card is a great overkill.

I opted for it as I like to record gameplay and upload also there is a good chance I will be upgrading my monitor within this year. so I wanted to make sure I don't get any issues while recording. This is how I personally was able to justify paying such a premium.

I'm sure this card can pull 1440p easily with RTX ON with frames somewhere around 80 FPs
with RTX Of however you can expect to be able to run 4K Games at 60 FPS stable without any issues

The following is just my humble opinion:
If you fall under any other category, other than what I mentioned above, I strongly suggest you look for more reviews or wait this one out (assuming you don't care about RTX) based on your personal situation. For example playing 4K with RTX on Max using this card isn't going to happen you will need to get the 2080 TI for that. If you have a monitor with anything higher than 120 FPS like the 144, you should also consider the 2080 TI.
From what I gathered the new RTX 2060 Lineup should be able to get a 60 FPS gameplay at 1080p with RTX settings at Medium so this could also be an option for you if you are a 1080p gamer.

The new RTX Lineup is rather complicated more than usual but due to that complication it also offers a great variety of options. That's why my final advice would be to take your time and read/watch reviews, benchmarks, and study your specific case carefully (Your monitor Resolution & Frames, RTX Settings you want, possibility of upgrading your monitor in the close future).

International Shoppers rejoice:
If you live in Kuwait I'm guessing the rest of the gulf as well, Amazon now ships directly to Kuwait in record times, Door to Door with full tracking and decent fees (make sure its Amazon Global Service). Thank you Amazon!

Reviews.title: Absolutely Silent without fans running, Still Quiet when they do
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2019
Reviews.text:
So, been using this for a few months now and I couldn't be more pleased...except for the price, which I think is inflated by a couple hundred $$. Then again, it does something I've never achieved before with any other GPU....

My objective for my new PC was total fan-less silence when I'm not gaming...and relative quiet even when I do.

The huge heatsink on this EVGA GPU (along with a 360mm Corsair AIO for my conservatively overclocked i7-9700k) are the key elements which allowed me to do this. The radiators are so massive that the entire systems stays very cool even without the fans spinning.

I installed it all inside a roomy Define R6 along with a few slow and quiet 140mm fans for those moments when the GPU/CPU combo are heavily active, and honestly even then...under heavy load...it's still much quieter then my previous machine was idle.

I should also note that I did NOT install the EVGA Precision X control software when I first installed the card, intending to later as I have with all my previous EVGA cards...but this one has run so flawlessly that I haven't even bothered. The stock curve on mine doesn't seem to spin up fans until ~60c, and I can see via HWMONITOR that my card never even approaches near those temps until I game. Even then though the fans are large enough, and the rpm's slow enough, that I have to put my ear up against the case to hear anything.

Performance wise, it's not quite the quantum leap that I was expecting from my previous GTX980...it feels twice as fast, and my benchmarks more then confirm so, but I expect that when I skip a generation. I have noticed and appreciated the additional memory (8GB vs 6GB in my old 980) allowing me to load more highly textured and detailed settings at 4K resolutions when I play TW:Warhammer. That game sometimes maxed my 980's memory out and would "swap" if you will to my machines primary memory, which sometimes resulted in buggy behavior.

Reviews.title: Purchased FTW3 April 8th, 2019 @ $1,300. 2 1/2 years later it still bangs hard in a second PC.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2021
Reviews.text:
I bought it as an upgrade to my old Alienware Area-51 desktop (the triangle shaped one) I bought in 2015.
It performed admirably, and really opened my computer up to a ton of high end games at great quality.

I have since moved on and built a tower from ibuypower. I got a 3090 ROG Strix white edition with 10900k cpu / 32GB ram.. and I have to say, that this 2080 is still a monster. Keeps up extremely well with all modern games, and makes me wonder why I even upgraded. I rebuilt my wife's computer (upgraded her CPU, RAM, and replaced her gpu with this 2080). Our systems are almost equal, of course mine can do more things with the VRAM, but good lord I feel like this 2080 is going to last for another 3 or 4 years until it even begins to struggle. And that's a hard maybe on the struggling. Bottom line, this card is awesome. Was gut wrenching to buy on day 1, but stoked with it in the end.

Reviews.title: Evga rtx 2080 review.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2019
Reviews.text: So I wasn't going to spend an over price of 1000+ dollars for 2080 ti which is ridiculous btw, so the next best option was this of course why not just go with a 1080 ti well number 1 it doesn't use next gen gddr6 memory 2 it doesn't have raytracying an 3 this card seems to be a bit more powerful in my experience.overall it was a great buy to say the least an I haven't yet overclocked it yet but so far the preformance from a 2060 to 2080 is really good over 150+ frames on most games even competitive games like multiplayer. I don't really have any complaints well constructive complaints that is. The card is smooth buttery smooth at least with my system being 2700x rtx 2080 and the card stays cool and quiet I haven't had the card go over 65c yet of course I haven't oc it yet so that could change but base settings it stays around 59 - 63c for me of course I have 6 fans blowing out heat so that has some factor in it. Only con I have is well idk if u can at least I haven't figured the bloody thing out yet is I can't change the rgb lighting from that ugly blue dull color to a color of my choosing that I would like. In fact I would rather them not even put an rgb feature on it as the card is beautiful by its self an rgb literally does nothing but eat up more power for the system so yea ill pass on that. All in all

Reviews.title: Awesome, powerful and quiet GPU
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2019
Reviews.text:
Despite people saying that a RTX 2080 is not a worthy upgrade if you have a GTX 1080, reviews online were not saying that way so I decided to do it. I read a review stating that the Evga XC Ultra was performing as good as the founder edition but with less heat and noise so I ordered it and I could not be happier. This beast can run everything you throw at it without any problem. For instance, my Gigabyte GTX 1080 was having a hard time to go above 90 fps at 2K and ultra settings in Battlefield V but this one runs it at above 120 fps most of the time. If I enable ray tracing and set it at ultra the frame rate drops at 70 fps but it's still very smooth and the images are beautiful.

Moreover the card temperature never goes above 65C and is always dead silent even with a more aggressive fan speed curve set in Precision X1. Speaking of Precision X1, I managed to do a decent overclocking with this easy to use software. To be honest I prefer MSI afterburner but to make sure I have the optimal stability I am using the Evga software (for now) and it's pretty good too. The RGB control is also easy with the software and it looks nice in my case (see picture).

Of course if someone is struggling to pay his rent I would say stick with your GTX 1080 but if you have the money, a powerful enough CPU and want a substantial fps boost I highly recommend this GPU.

Reviews.title: Absolute Beast
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2020
Reviews.text:
I bought this card back in 2019 but I think after running this thing pretty hard every single day I need to review it and give some insight.

This thing is an absolute monster. If you want all the frames you can push in any game you play, this card is for you. I run a 1440p 144hz monitor as my main and 2 4K monitors as my second and third monitors and it absolutely handles everything I’ve ever thrown at it. The noise level is minimal, and the performance has been more than perfect. I’ve been playing a few different games recently with an emphasis on Modern Warfare, and I don’t think I’ve ever gone below 130fps in game, even with cluster strikes, precision air strikes, or chopper gunners active on a small map like shipment. It makes ever sports game look surreal and it is an absolute power house of a card and should stay a power house of a card for years to come. This is a really good investment for at least 4-5 years into the future of gaming and will perform admirably.

Obviously your experience may change depending on type of motherboard, processor, ram, etc. but if you’re in the market and have the cash, there’s really no other choice besides the more premier cards just above this but performance on those will be negligible. Give it a whirl.

Reviews.title: What can I say...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2018
Reviews.text: This card is a SIGNIFICANT upgrade to my THREE (3) GTX-980's in several ways: 1. It's ONE card, meaning much lower power. 2. It's one card meaning much lower heat generation. I see no more than 50 DEG C in my setup, whereas before I was seeing at least one of the three cards topping 80's often. 3. Takes all three of my monitors, and my HTC Vive connected. I learned that Vive only works direct through the HDMI, and not through a converted display port connection. I had to find the "right" setup with the other 3 cards to make sure it worked. Having 12 ports doesn't mean you can plug in 12 things. 4. It takes up a LOT less space in my case, so the whole thing is lighter. 5. I do not hear this card at all. The others I could hear especially when one would heat up. 6. The card snapped it in less than 1 minute, and I didn't even need to upgrade the drivers. I did so anyway, just to be sure, but it set itself up just fine, with three monitors (non-surround) just like I had it before. 7. I have yet to see GPU usage above 80% on anything. I have everything I play maxed. The only time it peaked was when I ran the MSI Kumbustor performance check. 8. It has more, faster memory than those three 980's combined. 9. No SLI messing around. 10. I buy EVGA because they are quality built. I've never had one fail on me. This one is built solid and the fan set up is a work of art (to a mechanical engineer...). Bottom line: Very happy with my long awaited upgrade.

Reviews.title: Built my first gaming PC with this
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2019
Reviews.text:
I knew next to nothing about building a PC so I did a fair amount of research before pulling the trigger on this GPU when Amazon had it on sale around Black Friday. I wanted a GPU that would be able to handle almost anything I threw at it and would be good for years to come. This thing definitely puts the PS4 Pro that I switched over from to shame. The difference in graphics is night and day. Describing graphics or performance is silly though, you should just check out the UserBenchmark stats and see what you'll get before you buy.

I've had a great experience with this GPU thus far. I did come across a critical system error that had my PC randomly rebooting itself and it ultimately seemed to be caused by the drivers on this, so I simply uninstalled them and reinstalled them and haven't had the problem since. Along with the rest of my PC, I've been able to run any game at ultra settings without performance issues and I haven't messed around with any overclocking on any parts either. The fans on this are effective at keeping it cool and they're nice and quiet ( I can't even hear them over my CPU fan and case fans). EVGA's "Precision" software that you can get for free off their website is essential because it enables you to change the fan settings, the LED colors, and tune the GPU's voltage and clock speed.

Reviews.title: Very VERY fast! Very power efficient. Upgrade now!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2019
Reviews.text:
If you're looking at a NVIDIA 2080 you may be trying to decide if you should upgrade from your previous graphics card and which version of the 2080 to get, the flashy Ti or Titans are very tempting .

I was confused which graphics card to order, since there are so many variants. I think the biggest thing that sold me on EVGA is their upgrade path, the ability to upgrade if a better card comes out on the market in a short time or if you need more performance.

I can say without a doubt while accounting the price of this graphics card - it's amazing and very fast.

First up the good:
This graphics card runs VERY cool , if you're worried about heat these new generation of graphics cards are amazing. If it doesn't need to spin up it won't. In most cases people just are running simple items on their computer like youtube, facebook, email, and website. This card won't create a ton of heat when idle.
VERY fast, when you demand the power, this card will be faster than most cards on the market. You can get faster, but it depends how much money you want to spend for an extra 10% performance. Start small and if you notice you need faster just call up EVGA and upgrade! A lot of people over purchase on their computer parts. You can quickly test what you need this way.

I wouldn't improve anything, this card is great!

Great product overall, and well worth the price! Start your gaming or studio work now!

Reviews.title: Great Card - but Support is hard to find
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2020
Reviews.text: This is a great card, works find. Had an issue with the OS not seeing the card and not allowing me to install drivers. NVIDIAs site steers you to this community support page where there's some advice but response is slow and so on... They should post a large ONLINE CHAT link and man it. It turned out my problem was very simple. Windows 10 needs to be at build 1800 or later and mine was like 200 mini builds behind that. Not your nightly update, that didn't work. You have to go to Microsoft and pull the latest build updates from MAY and that fixes it. Then everything works. Great technology. Support needs to be improved with more information readily available. I actually figured this one out by going to the website of my mother boards manufacturer. ASUS makes quality products and puts decent information on how to solve stuff on their site.

Reviews.title: Shipped on time and installed well.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2020
Reviews.text: I bought this for my son to enhance his computer gaming experience. We took out the old graphics card and put in this new one by ourselves. The old card didn't need a power supply, but this new one did to run the fans I believe. So we had to find the extra male end wire that was wire tied in with a bunch of other wires coming off the power supply and feed it to the other side of the computer so the graphics card could get power. Make sure you have the room for the larger graphics card and your computer has the additional power supply. It all went pretty smooth and the it works fine going on a month now and no problems. I hope you have as good of luck as we did.

Reviews.title: Great graphics card!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2020
Reviews.text: Over the holidays I tried out a few graphics cards within the price range of the 2070. From Radeon 5700 to GTX 1080. Every card had some sort of issue that bothered me. This RTX 2070 was exactly what I was looking for. It has great power and I haven't even begun to push it with any overclocking. It has slightly more processing power than a 2060 super does, which is relevant because I purchased the card brand new for $399, which is equal to the value of a 2060 super. The card runs very quiet and even when I play intense games it barely ramps up in noise levels. If you're looking for a graphics card around $400 this is the one to get hands down!

Reviews.title: Excellent Value & Performance!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2020
Reviews.text: Tried 3 other cards that disabled my NVMe SSD drive upon install, not this time. This Gigabyte card RTX 2070 card installed flawlessly. It has 3 Display Ports & 1 HDMI - I'm using a 3 monitor 4K DP setup and it works very well with no fan running for business & light gaming use. On the few heavier games I've tried, I've maxed settings at 4K and am not hearing the fan ramping up as of yet. So far, I'm extremely pleased with this unit. Drivers have been very stable and the utilities provide a lot of information but haven't otherwise been useful.

Reviews.title: RTX 2070 on a "budget"
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2020
Reviews.text: I bought this for my son after his older AMD graphics board crapped out after 5 years. Right now it seems that the rtx 2070 is still a better value than the rtx 2060 super, or at least this version is. It is the "no frills" version though. No rgb lights and lighter non-metal backplate. In fact, the board seems unusually light in general. During gaming it's venting just under 40C air out the back right at the case frame. Haven't done any further checks. Noise doesn't seem to be an issue. Haven't heard any coil whine or excessive noise from the fans.

Reviews.title: Good performance, bad fan control.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2020
Reviews.text: The card works great, does well with my 3 monitor setup which has a 4k monitor and 2 lesser resolution monitors. The only complaint is that the fans randomly spin up full blast for about 1 second and then back down which is super annoying. I tried to mess with the fan control app but that didnt do anything. I contacted support about it and after giving me the run around following the "script". All leading up to them asking me to return it, but then I have to pay to have it shipped back just for them to send me another card which will likely do the same thing. As it turns out this is a common issue with this manufacturer, they fixed it on another line of cards with a firmware update so I hope one might come soon. Although when I tried the firmware update tool, it failed to connect and check for updates.

Reviews.title: Awesome card for multi-monitor setup
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2020
Reviews.text: This card is used to support 3 monitors (4 planned later on) in a business setting doing graphic design work. Setup was easy. It has 4 ports, one HDMI and the other three are Display Port. There are cheap adapters to convert Display Port to HDMI or VGA. Initially, using the monitors we currently have, we're using 1 HDMI connection and and 2 Display-Port to VGA connections and it's working well. We will later switch to 4 HDMI monitors. Very happy with this card!

Reviews.title: Excellent for a mid to high range gamer
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2020
Reviews.text: Since the release of the RTX Super series, the regular RTX line has witnessed a good drop in price. I wouldn't discount the regular RTX series in any way - IMO the Supers are overkill. Though it seems a little high in price, it is very much worth it. No problems whatsoever installing mine. Runs games smoothly with no choppiness while simultaneously maxing out any game I throw at it. Excellent card.

Reviews.title: Absolute mess
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2020
Reviews.text: With the global card shortage, this would have been great. Except it was shipped in the retail packaging - no outer box. Smashed on arrival. Delicate electronics should be protected better. Otherwise the Windforce is a great card and it would have been nice to game and edit with. Even with the exaggerated price when compared to newer architectures. Law of supply and demand though.

Reviews.title: Better then the 1660 super
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2020
Reviews.text: This thing is a beast for the money. I’m playing most games at 1440p with 90-120fps. I have it paired with a x570 pro with a Ryzen 7 3700x. i get about 90-120 fps on apex 1440p high settings. i payed $400 USD for this
